events.title: Portland Parks & Recreation Access Discount Program

pricing.notes: No proof of income required - self-select discount level

events.notes: Flagship program - most impactful discount in the region

practical_tips.first_visit: Register online at portland.gov/parks - no office visit needed
practical_tips.registration: Self-select your discount level (25-90%) based on your situation - no proof required
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Just your account info to register
practical_tips.good_to_know: This is the most flexible discount program in the region. You choose your own discount level with complete privacy - no income verification, no paperwork. Works for classes, pool passes, community center memberships, and more.

pricing.notes: Present Oregon Trail Card at venue

practical_tips.first_visit: Just show your Oregon Trail Card at the ticket window - no pre-registration needed
practical_tips.registration: None required - just present your EBT card at participating venues
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Oregon Trail Card (SNAP/EBT) and valid ID
practical_tips.good_to_know: Works at 100+ venues including Portland Art Museum, OMSI, Oregon Zoo, Japanese Garden, Oregon Symphony, Portland Opera, and theaters. Most venues allow same-day walk-up. Check individual venue hours and any timed-entry requirements. Some venues may have blackout dates for special exhibitions.

events.title: THPRD Financial Aid Program

pricing.description: $300 per person annually in fee waivers
pricing.notes: Funds valid for 12 months from approval. Can be allocated flexibly across family members.

events.notes: Winter 2026 session at capacity; reopens February 2, 2026 for Spring registration. One application per household yearly. Unused funds expire annually.

practical_tips.first_visit: Submit application online, by email, or in-person at any THPRD facility before registering for programs
practical_tips.registration: Apply once per household per year. Wait for approval (10 business days) before signing up for classes. Funds can be split flexibly among family members.
practical_tips.what_to_bring: One proof of income (tax returns, SNAP/TANF letters, pay stubs, SSA awards, or unemployment benefits)
practical_tips.good_to_know: $300 per person annually covers general classes, community garden plots, facility rentals, birthday parties, childcare, and youth sports leagues. English and Spanish applications available. Unused funds expire after 12 months.

events.title: Portland General Electric Income-Qualified Bill Discount

pricing.notes: No proof of income required

practical_tips.first_visit: Apply online at portlandgeneral.com - takes about 5 minutes
practical_tips.registration: Self-certify your income online. No documentation required. Discount starts on next billing cycle.
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Just your PGE account number
practical_tips.good_to_know: This is one of the easiest assistance programs to apply for - completely online, no paperwork, no income verification. The discount (15-80%) is based on your self-reported income level. Can save hundreds of dollars annually.

pricing.notes: No income documentation required at application

practical_tips.first_visit: Apply online, by email, mail, or phone - choose whichever is easiest for you
practical_tips.registration: No income documentation required at application. If you've received LIHEAP/OEAP, you may be auto-enrolled at 20% discount.
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Your Pacific Power account number
practical_tips.good_to_know: Discount lasts 2 years before needing to recertify. If you received LIHEAP/OEAP assistance, you're auto-renewed. The 40% discount tier is for households with income 0-20% of state median. Also waives late fees, reconnection fees, and deposits.

pricing.example: Household of 4, income <$17,697: 85% discount = $644 annual savings on avg $758 bill
pricing.notes: No proof of income required, lasts 2 years, stackable with other assistance

practical_tips.first_visit: Apply online, by email, mail, or phone - takes about 10 minutes
practical_tips.registration: No proof of income required. Self-certify your household income. Discount lasts 2 years.
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Your NW Natural account number and household size/income info
practical_tips.good_to_know: Stackable with other energy assistance programs. Besides the 15-85% bill discount, you also get no late fees, no reconnection fees, and no deposits. Available in English, Spanish, Russian, Chinese, and Vietnamese.

pricing.description: Spend $1 SNAP on produce, get $1 match (up to $20/day)

practical_tips.first_visit: Go to the market info booth first to get your Double Up tokens
practical_tips.registration: No registration needed. Just use your SNAP/EBT card at participating farmers markets.
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Oregon Trail Card (SNAP/EBT)
practical_tips.good_to_know: Spend $1 on fruits and veggies with SNAP, get $1 match free (up to $20/day). Works at PSU, King, Beaverton, Hollywood, Montavilla, and Woodstock farmers markets. Look for vendors with the Double Up Food Bucks sign. Great way to stretch your food budget on fresh, local produce.

events.title: NCPRD Scholarship Program

pricing.notes: Percentage based on income and household size

events.notes: Limited scholarship funds available - aimed at maximizing number of participants served

practical_tips.first_visit: Contact Recreation Services at 503-794-8080 or email recreation@ncprd.com to request an application
practical_tips.registration: Apply before registering for programs - scholarships must be pre-approved. Do not register for classes until you receive scholarship confirmation.
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Proof of NCPRD district residency (address verification required)
practical_tips.good_to_know: Partial scholarships only (25-75% off) - some financial contribution expected from all participants. Limited to 3 program areas per person per year. All applications kept confidential. Limited funds available, so apply early.

events.title: Lake Oswego Parks & Recreation Scholarship
events.notes: Financial assistance for Lake Oswego residents to access recreation programs.

practical_tips.first_visit: Call 503-675-2549 to request a scholarship application
practical_tips.registration: Apply through Parks & Recreation office. Scholarship valid for fiscal year (July 1 - June 30). Only household members listed on application are eligible.
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Proof of income and Lake Oswego residency
practical_tips.good_to_know: Maximum $300 per person, $600 per family per fiscal year. Covers recreation classes, fitness activities, summer camps, and enrichment programs. Must be Lake Oswego resident with household income below Federal Free Meal Guidelines.

events.title: Tualatin Recreation Scholarship Program
events.notes: City scholarship program to ensure recreation access for all Tualatin children regardless of income.

practical_tips.first_visit: Email info@tualatintogether.org to request scholarship application and information
practical_tips.registration: Email info@tualatintogether.org for scholarship application. Must demonstrate financial need and Tualatin residency.
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Proof of Tualatin residency and financial need documentation
practical_tips.good_to_know: City program focused on ensuring no child is denied recreational opportunities due to financial limitations. Covers recreation programs and summer camps. Contact Tualatin Together directly for current availability and application process.

events.title: MHCC Senior Tuition Discount

pricing.age_65_plus: FREE tuition for up to 8 credits (audit) for Oregon residents 65+
pricing.notes: Fees not included in discount

events.notes: Oregon seniors 65+ can audit college classes free. Great for lifelong learners.

practical_tips.first_visit: Contact admissions to learn about enrollment process
practical_tips.registration: Standard enrollment process; bring ID for age verification
practical_tips.what_to_bring: ID, proof of residency
practical_tips.good_to_know: Great way for seniors to take classes for personal enrichment

pricing.notes: Free first month + free Hop card upon enrollment

practical_tips.first_visit: Apply online at trimet.org/income or visit TriMet Ticket Office at Pioneer Courthouse Square
practical_tips.registration: Online application takes 5-10 minutes. Auto-qualify if you receive OHP, SNAP, TANF, Section 8, or LIHEAP. Otherwise provide proof of income.
practical_tips.what_to_bring: For in-person - proof of public benefits OR income verification, photo ID
practical_tips.good_to_know: First month FREE plus a free Hop card when you enroll. Half-price fares ($1.40 vs $2.80) and monthly pass ($28 vs $100). Works on all TriMet buses, MAX, WES, and Portland Streetcar. Auto-renews annually if still on qualifying benefits.

events.title: NAMI Multnomah

programs.name: Connection Peer Support (In-Person)
programs.location: Community for Positive Aging, 1820 NE 40th Ave, Portland OR 97212

programs.name: LGBTQ2SIA+ Support
programs.eligibility: LGBTQ2SIA+ adults 18+ with mental health symptoms

programs.name: BIPOC Peer Support
programs.eligibility: Black, Indigenous, and/or People of Color adults with mental health conditions

programs.name: Complex Trauma & Dissociation Support
programs.eligibility: Those experiencing complex trauma and/or dissociation

events.notes: No diagnosis required for any groups. Groups are peer-led by trained volunteers with lived experience.

practical_tips.first_visit: Just show up to any meeting - no pre-registration needed for most groups
practical_tips.registration: Some groups require registration via email/phone - check schedule
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Nothing required; Zoom link sent after registration for virtual groups
practical_tips.good_to_know: Peer-led by volunteers with lived experience. No diagnosis required. Safe to share or just listen.

events.title: NAMI Clackamas

programs.name: NAMI Connection Support Group
programs.notes: For adults living with mental health conditions. Registration required.

programs.name: Women (18+) Only Support Group
programs.notes: Bi-weekly peer-led recovery support

programs.name: NAMI Family Support Group
programs.notes: For anyone who cares about someone with mental health condition. Call to register.

programs.name: Spanish-Speaking Support Group
programs.notes: Peer-led for Spanish-speaking adults with mental health conditions

programs.name: LGBTQ+ Support Group
programs.notes: Joint program with NAMI Multnomah - weekly for adults 18+

programs.name: Suicide Bereavement Support Group
programs.notes: Hosted by NAMI Clackamas for those bereaved by suicide

events.notes: Registration required for most groups. All groups free and peer-led by trained volunteers with lived experience.

practical_tips.first_visit: Call or email to register for your first meeting
practical_tips.registration: Registration required - call 503-344-5050 or check website
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Nothing required; virtual groups send Zoom link after registration
practical_tips.good_to_know: Spanish-speaking group available. Women's group meets in-person in Milwaukie. All peer-led.

events.title: CMHC Peer Groups (Clackamas Mental Health Clinic)
events.address: 11211 SE 82nd Ave Suite O, Portland, OR 97086

programs.name: ColorFlow
programs.notes: A welcoming art group for creative self-expression and mindfulness through paint. Explore emotions, connect with others, and find calm through color. No art experience needed.

programs.name: Intentional Silence & Meditation
programs.notes: A peaceful, grounding space to slow down, breathe, and reconnect with yourself. Explore stillness, mindfulness, and the power of silence as a way to rest, reflect, and find calm in community.

programs.name: Cultivate & Connect
programs.notes: A grounding art group exploring creativity, connection, and mindfulness through nature. Inspired by natural materials and the senses, celebrating growth, self-expression, and community through hands-on creation.

programs.name: Healing with Photography
programs.notes: A creative group for exploring healing, identity, and self-expression. Using photography as a mindful practice to reflect on experiences, notice moments of beauty, and connect.

programs.name: Karaoke Night
programs.notes: An open space for joy, laughter, and self-expression through song. Come as you are — sing solo, join in with others, or cheer from the crowd as we build confidence, connection, and community through music.

events.notes: Groups led by peers for individuals already connected with Clackamas County Peer Support services. Groups paused in January 2026, resuming February 2026.

practical_tips.first_visit: Stop by the clinic to get connected with a Peer Support Specialist if you don't already have one
practical_tips.registration: Must be receiving Peer Support services in Clackamas County to attend
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Nothing required - just yourself
practical_tips.good_to_know: Groups are peer-led and focus on creative, mindful, and connection-focused activities. Great variety from art to meditation to karaoke.

events.title: FolkTime Peer Connection Centers
events.notes: Founded 1985, one of Oregon's oldest peer-run programs. Free membership. Orientation required for new members.

practical_tips.first_visit: Attend orientation on 2nd or 3rd Wednesday of any month
practical_tips.registration: Email peerconnection@folktime.org or just show up to orientation
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Nothing required; $1 donation suggested for collective lunch
practical_tips.good_to_know: Oregon's oldest peer-run program (1985). Drop-in, no referral needed. Arrive by 11am to join collective lunch prep.

events.title: NorthStar Clubhouse
events.notes: Portland's first Clubhouse International Community. Program of New Narrative. Clubhouse model emphasizes strengths over symptoms.

practical_tips.first_visit: Contact to schedule an orientation first - referral from mental health professional required
practical_tips.registration: Call 971-271-7273 to start the referral and orientation process
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Just yourself; lunch is provided
practical_tips.good_to_know: Clubhouse model: members work alongside staff on meaningful tasks. Focus on strengths, not symptoms. Employment and education support available.

events.title: New Narrative Comfort Zone
events.address: 10130 SW Nimbus Ave, Suite D2, Tigard, OR 97223
events.notes: Peer-run program for adults not ready for formal treatment. Staffed by peer support specialists with lived experience of mental health challenges. Contact: 503-726-3690

practical_tips.first_visit: Just walk in during open hours - no appointment needed
practical_tips.registration: No registration required, just drop in
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Nothing required; snacks and activities provided
practical_tips.good_to_know: Tigard area location. Job and housing support available. Call for current group schedule.

events.title: Behavioral Health Resource Center
events.address: 333 SW Park Ave (at SW Oak St), Portland, OR
events.notes: Pets allowed; no ID, sobriety, or cleanliness required. Managed by The Peer Company (formerly MHAAO). Does NOT offer detox, safe-use spaces, or emergency services.

practical_tips.first_visit: Get a ticket from the outreach van at NW Broadway & Glisan (6am-2pm) to access day center
practical_tips.registration: First-come first-served, 25 people per 3-hour block
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Nothing required; showers, laundry, phone charging available
practical_tips.good_to_know: No ID, sobriety, or cleanliness required. Pets allowed. Shelter and bridge housing also available (call waitlist).

events.title: DBSA Portland (Depression Bipolar Support Alliance)

programs.name: Mental Healthcare Professionals
programs.notes: For healthcare professionals living with mood disorders. Peer support in a confidential space.

events.notes: Peer-facilitated support groups since 2005. Typical attendance 10-25 people. Three chapters: Eastside, West Portland, and LGBTQ. All meetings free and drop-in.

practical_tips.first_visit: Just join any Zoom meeting - drop-in, no registration needed
practical_tips.registration: Eastside group uses Meetup for registration; others just show up
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Computer/phone for Zoom; first Monday LGBTQ+ meeting is hybrid
practical_tips.good_to_know: Not just for depression/bipolar - open to ALL mental health conditions. Typical attendance 10-25 people. Running since 2005.

events.title: David Romprey Oregon Warmline
events.notes: Non-crisis peer phone support using Intentional Peer Support (IPS) framework. Staffed by trained peers with lived experience of mental health challenges, moods, voices, visions, trauma, and addictions. No appointments needed.

practical_tips.first_visit: Just call anytime - 24/7, no appointment needed
practical_tips.registration: No registration, just dial and talk
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Nothing - just a phone
practical_tips.good_to_know: NOT a crisis line - for connection and support. Spanish line available. Staffed by peers with lived experience.

events.title: Recovery Dharma Portland (PDX)

programs.name: Middle Way on MLK
programs.location: True Colors Recovery, 3807 NE MLK Jr Blvd

programs.name: Dharma Rain Eightfold Path Study
programs.location: Dharma Rain Zen Center, 8500 NE Siskiyou St

programs.name: Sarpashana
programs.location: Portland Insight Meditation Center, 6536 SE Duke St

events.notes: 30+ weekly meetings across Portland. Buddhist-based recovery using mindfulness and loving-kindness - alternative to 12-step programs.

practical_tips.first_visit: Just show up to any meeting - all welcome beginners
practical_tips.registration: No registration needed
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Nothing required; cushions usually available
practical_tips.good_to_know: Buddhist-based but non-religious. 30+ meetings weekly. Specialty groups for LGBTQIA+, women/trans/NB. Alternative to 12-step.

events.title: The Peer Company (formerly MHAAO)
events.address: 2740 SE Powell Blvd Suite 3, Portland, OR 97202
events.notes: Rebranded from MHAAO September 2025. Free peer support services throughout Portland metro. Walk-in locations available.

practical_tips.first_visit: Walk in to Recovery Campus (SE Powell) or CATT (Hillsboro) during business hours
practical_tips.registration: No appointment needed for walk-in support
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Nothing required
practical_tips.good_to_know: Free peer support for both mental health AND substance use. Also offers peer specialist training programs.

events.title: Q Center Portland (LGBTQ+ Community Center)

programs.name: Trans PDX Support Group
programs.notes: For trans, nonbinary, agender, gender-fabulous folks

programs.name: LGBTQIA2S+ Mental Health Support
programs.schedule: Mondays 7-8:30pm (virtual; 1st & 3rd Mondays hybrid at Q Center)
programs.notes: Peer-led for anxiety, depression, bipolar, PTSD

programs.name: QTIBIPOC Community Space
programs.notes: For queer, trans, intersex BIPOC community members

events.notes: Portland's LGBTQ+ community center. Safe space with multi-generational programs. Many support groups and weekly events.

practical_tips.first_visit: Check website for current group schedule and drop in
practical_tips.registration: Most groups drop-in; some use Discord for virtual
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Nothing required
practical_tips.good_to_know: Portland's LGBTQ+ community hub. Trans support, mental health groups, QTIBIPOC space. Safe and welcoming.

events.title: Dual Diagnosis Anonymous (DDA) Oregon
events.notes: 12-Step plus 5 additional steps for co-occurring mental illness and substance use. Peer-led meetings.

practical_tips.first_visit: Just show up to any meeting - daily noon meetings downtown most accessible
practical_tips.registration: No registration needed
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Nothing required
practical_tips.good_to_know: 17-step program designed for co-occurring mental health AND substance use. Daily meetings Mon-Fri plus Saturday.

events.title: Portland Area Intergroup of Alcoholics Anonymous

programs.name: In-Person Meetings
programs.schedule: 900+ meetings per week in Portland area
programs.notes: Open, closed, speaker, and specialized meetings

events.notes: No dues or fees. No requirements - anyone who wants to stop drinking is welcome. Meeting Guide app available for iOS/Android.

practical_tips.first_visit: Use pdxaa.org or Meeting Guide app to find a meeting near you
practical_tips.registration: No registration - just show up
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Nothing required
practical_tips.good_to_know: 900+ meetings weekly in Portland area. 24-hour phone support. Open meetings welcome anyone; closed meetings for alcoholics only.

events.title: The Dougy Center for Grieving Children & Families

programs.name: Children's Grief Support (ages 3-12)
programs.notes: For children who have lost parent, caregiver, or sibling

programs.name: Teen Grief Support (ages 13-18)
programs.notes: For teens who have lost parent, caregiver, sibling, or close friend

programs.name: Young Adult Groups (19-25, 26-40)
programs.notes: For young adults grieving significant loss

programs.name: Esperanza (Spanish-language)
programs.notes: Bilingual peer grief support for Spanish-speaking families

events.notes: Pioneering peer grief support model since 1982. World-renowned programs. Also offers training and resources for professionals.

practical_tips.first_visit: Call to learn about intake process and current group availability
practical_tips.registration: Intake required - call 503-775-5683
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Nothing required for groups
practical_tips.good_to_know: World-renowned pioneering grief program since 1982. Groups for all ages from 3 to 40+. Spanish-language groups available.

events.title: Providence Hospice Grief Support Groups
events.notes: Open to anyone grieving the death of a significant person. Free and no registration required.

practical_tips.first_visit: Call 503-215-4622 for current group schedule and registration
practical_tips.registration: Call for current schedule
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Nothing required
practical_tips.good_to_know: Hospital-based but open to anyone grieving. Professional facilitators. Groups meet at various times - call for schedule.

events.title: 4D Recovery

programs.name: Drop-In Center
programs.notes: Welcoming space with pool table, video games, TV, and peer connection. Come hang out, no pressure.

programs.name: Recovery Support Meetings
programs.notes: 12-step, dharma, yoga, and social recovery approaches available. Check website for current schedule.

events.notes: Youth-focused (14-35) recovery community with peer mentors
events.practical_tips: Peer-led recovery community for young people ages 14-35. Drop-in centers with games, meetings, and social events. Certified peer mentors with lived experience. Accepts Medicaid/OHP. Also has Hillsboro location.

events.title: PeerGalaxy Online Wellness Portal
events.notes: Comprehensive Oregon peer support portal - find virtual and in-person groups
events.practical_tips: Searchable online calendar with 392,000+ peer support offerings statewide. Includes support groups, chair yoga, Tai-Chi, breathwork, guided art, grief support. Created by The Peer Company (formerly MHAAO).

events.title: SMART Recovery Portland
events.schedule: Multiple weekly meetings across Portland metro
events.notes: Science-based addiction recovery meetings - good alternative for those seeking non-spiritual approach
events.practical_tips: Evidence-based, non-spiritual alternative to 12-step programs. Uses cognitive behavioral techniques. Meetings in all Portland quadrants plus online. No lifetime commitment - attend as long as helpful.

practical_tips.first_visit: Stop by the front desk to sign up for a day pass or ask about memberships
practical_tips.registration: Drop-in welcome. North Portland residents get FREE access with proof of address.
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Towel, lock for locker, swimsuit if using pool
practical_tips.good_to_know: Historic center in North Portland's Eliot neighborhood. Has indoor pool, gym, and fitness center. The 90% PPR discount makes drop-in only ~$0.60. Shower-only option available for $0.50.

events.title: Pier Park Disc Golf Course
events.address: N Bruce Ave & N James St (near N Lombard), Portland, OR 97203
events.notes: Summer and winter layouts available. Park hours 5am-midnight. One of top disc golf courses in the country.

practical_tips.first_visit: Park near the N Lombard entrance and look for tee signs
practical_tips.registration: None - just show up and play
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Discs (or borrow from friends). Water bottle recommended.
practical_tips.good_to_know: One of Portland's best courses - 18 holes winding through old-growth forest. Summer and winter layouts available. Intermediate to advanced, but welcoming to beginners. Can get crowded on weekends.

events.title: Rockwood Central Park Disc Golf Course
events.notes: Oregon's first disc golf course (established 1980)

practical_tips.first_visit: Course is in the southwest corner of the park, near the skate park
practical_tips.registration: None - just show up and play
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Discs and water. Benches available for rest breaks.
practical_tips.good_to_know: Oregon's first disc golf course, established 1980. Great for beginners with only 9 holes. Open layout is less intimidating than wooded courses. Part of a larger park with playground, sports courts, and splash pad.

events.title: Lunchtime Disc Golf Course
events.notes: Permanently closed as of July 2021

practical_tips.good_to_know: PERMANENTLY CLOSED - See Pier Park or Rockwood for alternatives

events.title: Yoga on Yamhill

pricing.notes: No one turned away for lack of funds

events.notes: Portland's oldest sliding-scale studio since 2010. Located in historic Franz building near MAX Blue Line. Sound bath every 2nd Sunday 10-11:30am.

practical_tips.first_visit: Just show up for any class - donation box on way out
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Mat if you have one
practical_tips.good_to_know: Oldest sliding-scale studio in Portland. Truly pay what you can.

events.title: BYMC (Bhakti Yoga Movement Center)

pricing.notes: South Asian, BIPOC, and queer-owned. No one turned away.

programs.name: Queer and Trans Yoga
programs.notes: Pre-registration suggested - often at capacity

programs.name: BIPOC-only Yoga
programs.notes: Pre-registration suggested - often at capacity

events.notes: Replaced Portland Yoga Collective entry (which is in Maine). BYMC offers weekly by-donation classes in SE Portland.

practical_tips.first_visit: Check website for current schedule and locations - classes held at various SE Portland venues
practical_tips.registration: Drop-in welcome at all classes. Pre-registration may be requested for some special events.
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Mat if you have one (some provided), water, comfortable clothes
practical_tips.good_to_know: Offers identity-affirming yoga including Queer and Trans Yoga, BIPOC-only Yoga, and general community classes. All by-donation with no one turned away. Great option if you've felt unwelcome in mainstream yoga spaces.

events.title: Dharma Rain Zen Center

programs.name: Sunday Morning Program
programs.details: 8:30 zazen, 9:00 kinhin, 9:40 chanting, 10:30 Dharma talk. All welcome.

programs.name: Weekday Morning Meditation
programs.details: Open zazen followed by brief chanting service

events.notes: Oldest and largest Soto Zen Buddhist temple in Oregon, founded 1975. All welcome at Sunday program. Practice advisors available for one-on-one guidance.

practical_tips.first_visit: Arrive 15-30 min early for orientation. Doors open 9am for Sunday program.
practical_tips.registration: None required - just show up. Newcomers welcome any Sunday.
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Comfortable clothes for sitting meditation. Cushions and chairs provided.
practical_tips.good_to_know: Oregon's oldest and largest Soto Zen Buddhist temple, founded 1975. Sunday program includes zazen (seated meditation), kinhin (walking meditation), chanting, and Dharma talk. Wednesday evening is simpler double-sit format. All welcome regardless of background.

events.title: Diamond Way Buddhist Center

programs.name: Guided Meditation
programs.notes: Guided meditation with explanation. Newcomers especially welcome.

programs.name: Guided Meditation
programs.notes: Guided meditation with explanation. Newcomers especially welcome.

events.notes: Karma Kagyu lineage of Tibetan Buddhism. Live-in center with guest room, near public transit. Founded 1997.

practical_tips.first_visit: Call 360-773-3770 for current location, then show up at 7pm on Monday or Thursday. Newcomers especially welcome.
practical_tips.registration: None required - drop-in welcome
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Nothing - cushions provided. Wear comfortable clothes.
practical_tips.good_to_know: Tibetan Buddhist center (Karma Kagyu lineage) offering guided meditation with explanation. Free always, no pressure. Live-in community center with guest room available. Near transit on NE 21st. Founded 1997.

events.title: Portland Insight Meditation Community (PIMC)

programs.name: Sunday Program
programs.details: Meditation, mindful movement, Dharma Talk. Doors open 9am for silent meditation.

programs.name: Heart of Freedom
programs.notes: Mindfulness cultivation class with Doug Pullin. Guided and silent meditation, teaching, and Q&A. Beginning and advanced students welcome.

events.notes: Vipassana (insight) tradition. Welcomes all faiths, orientations, genders, abilities, ages, and backgrounds.

practical_tips.first_visit: Arrive 15-20 min early on Sundays (doors open 9am for silent meditation). Tuesday evening is a simpler format.
practical_tips.registration: None required for weekly groups - just show up
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Comfortable clothes. Cushions and chairs provided. Online option available for some programs.
practical_tips.good_to_know: Vipassana (insight meditation) tradition in SE Portland. Dana (donation-based) so truly accessible. Sunday program includes meditation, mindful movement, and Dharma talk. Explicitly welcomes all faiths, orientations, genders, abilities, ages, and backgrounds.

events.title: East Portland Community Center

pricing.with_access_discount: Up to 90% off (no proof of income required)
pricing.notes: Non-residents pay higher rates. Children 0-2 FREE.

programs.name: TeenForce
programs.notes: Free access to drop-in activities with TeenForce pass

programs.name: Group Fitness Classes
programs.notes: Included with daily admission - strength, cardio, mind/body, dance

programs.name: Swim Lessons
programs.notes: 5 or 10-week sessions, registration required

events.notes: One of five PP&R community centers where TeenForce pass provides free access. Multi-visit passes work at all PP&R community centers.

practical_tips.first_visit: Register for Access Discount online before visiting to get reduced pricing

pricing.notes: Sign waiver before first run; no dogs

practical_tips.good_to_know: Four weekly runs - Monday trail (6pm), Tuesday track (6:30pm), Thursday social (6pm with bar after), Sunday long run (8am). All from NW Raleigh store except Tuesday. Sign waiver before first run, no dogs. Great way to meet other runners.

events.title: Food Court 5000 (Lloyd Center Mall Walking)
events.notes: 1980s-themed indoor mall walking. Dress code: neon leggings, acid-washed denim encouraged. Groups of 70+ regular attendees. Post-walk snacks at food court.

practical_tips.registration: None - just show up

practical_tips.good_to_know: 1980s-themed indoor mall walking led by Vera Mysteria. 3.5 mile route (2 laps, ~90 minutes). Rules - pump your arms, wave to passersby, no one walks alone. Post-walk snacks at food court. Groups of 70+ regular attendees. Very welcoming and fun community.

events.title: NeighborWalks
events.notes: AARP Oregon partnership. Ran 11 seasons from 2012-2022. Consider Portland Running Company, Lloyd Center, or Parks Dept programs as alternatives.

practical_tips.good_to_know: PROGRAM ENDED - Ran 11 seasons 2012-2022. Try Food Court 5000 (Lloyd Center), Portland Running Company, or Parks Dept walking programs instead.

practical_tips.first_visit: Check shift2bikes.org/calendar for current rides. Most list meeting location, time, and pace.
practical_tips.registration: None - rides are free and open to all
practical_tips.what_to_bring: Working bike, helmet recommended, lights for night rides, water
practical_tips.good_to_know: Portland's community bike ride calendar. Year-round rides including Monday Mixer, Foster Night Ride, Friday Night Ride. Pedalpalooza (June-August) features hundreds of free themed rides. Very welcoming culture - "bike fun" for all abilities.

pricing.description: FREE to try (no membership required initially)

practical_tips.what_to_bring: Working bike, helmet, water. E-bikes welcome on BITS rides.
practical_tips.good_to_know: Oregon's oldest bicycle club (founded 1896). BITS rides are specifically designed for beginners. More advanced riders can join regular club rides. Membership optional but supports the club.

events.title: YMCA of Columbia-Willamette

practical_tips.good_to_know: Free Friday Climbing (1st Friday 5-9pm) is free for SNAP/EBT holders, $5 for other Gresham residents. Teen Nights (1st & 3rd Saturdays 6-9pm) free for ages 13-18. May ask for ID to verify residency.

practical_tips.good_to_know: Doors open 7am daily for walkers before stores open. Climate-controlled, flat surfaces, benches for rest breaks. One loop is approximately 0.5 miles. Restrooms available. Quiet early morning hours are great for those who prefer avoiding crowds.

practical_tips.good_to_know: Opens 7am daily for walkers before stores open. Climate-controlled, flat surfaces, benches throughout. Close to TriMet bus lines. Early morning hours are quiet and uncrowded - ideal for those with social anxiety.

events.notes: Meditative slow-paced bird walks perfect for those seeking calm outdoor connection
events.practical_tips: Meditative, slow-paced bird walks (1-2 miles) on paved and dirt paths. No RSVP required. Extra binoculars available. Designed to be calming and accessible.

events.title: Tergar Meditation Community of Portland

programs.notes: Three 25-minute silent sitting sessions with walking meditation between, followed by tea, snacks, and social time.

programs.name: Weekly Online Meditation
programs.notes: Virtual meditation sessions for those who can't attend in person.

events.notes: Free monthly meditation with social time afterward. Beginner-friendly.
events.practical_tips: Free meditation practice in Hollywood District. Welcoming to beginners and experienced practitioners. Social time with tea and snacks after sitting. No registration needed.

programs.notes: Buddhist-inspired meditation with teaching and discussion. All traditions welcome.

programs.name: Daily Virtual Meditation
programs.notes: Consistent morning practice opportunity. Great for building routine.

events.practical_tips: No registration needed. Gift economy means pay what you can or nothing at all. Daily virtual option helps build consistent practice. Welcoming to all traditions.

events.address: Portland Shambhala Center (check Meetup for location)
events.notes: Meditation plus talking circle - good for those wanting both practice and connection
events.practical_tips: Partnership between Portland Shambhala Center and Young Meditators Group. 20 minutes silent meditation followed by talking circle. All traditions welcome. Good for connecting with others.

events.title: Portland Art Museum

pricing.description: $27.50 adults; FREE First Thursday; $5 Arts for All (EBT)

programs.name: Free First Thursday
programs.notes: Explore the museum's diverse collections for free. Tickets can be reserved online one week in advance or at the door. Often includes live DJs, guided tours, and special programming. Part of Portland's First Thursday arts tradition.

events.practical_tips: Free First Thursday 10am-7pm. Arts for All program provides $5 admission with EBT card (up to 4 tickets). Quieter on weekday mornings. Downtown location near PSU. Multiple floors with diverse collections.

events.title: OMSI (Oregon Museum of Science and Industry)

pricing.description: $20 adults regular; $5 First Sunday; $5 Arts for All (EBT)
pricing.notes: Arts for All provides up to 4 tickets at $5 each; 55% off memberships

programs.name: First Sunday
programs.notes: Discounted admission day - only $5 per person for all exhibits. Planetarium shows, submarine tours, and special exhibitions also $5 each. Purchase tickets online in advance to skip the line. Interactive science museum great for families and curious minds.

events.practical_tips: First Sunday is only $5 admission. Arts for All with EBT provides up to 4 tickets at $5 each and 55% off memberships. Interactive exhibits good for all ages. Can be crowded on weekends - weekday visits are quieter.

events.title: Academy Theater

pricing.notes: Exact prices vary - call or check website

events.notes: Independent dinner theater in Montavilla neighborhood.
events.practical_tips: Budget second-run theater with pizza and beer service. Three screens with reclining stadium seating. Less crowded than first-run theaters. Flying Pie Pizzeria on-site. Independent theater in Montavilla neighborhood.

events.title: Avalon Theatre & Wunderland

pricing.notes: Movie admission includes free arcade general admission

events.notes: Portland's oldest operating movie theater, in Sunnyside neighborhood.
events.practical_tips: Arrive early on discount days ($1.50 Tue-Thu) as it gets busy. The arcade section is included with movie admission. Quieter afternoon showings are best for avoiding crowds. Portland's oldest operating movie theater.

events.title: Laurelhurst Theater
events.notes: Theater and pub in Laurelhurst neighborhood.
events.practical_tips: Second-run films at low prices with full food and drink menu. Tuesday is $7 all day. Historic Art Deco theater with great atmosphere. Less crowded on weekday afternoons. 21+ only after 8pm.

events.title: Living Room Theaters
events.notes: Downtown near Powell's Books. Founded by filmmakers.
events.practical_tips: Upscale theater with luxury seating and full restaurant service. Check for $7 weekly indie film special at 7pm. Mon/Tue discount days. Reserve seats online to avoid lines. Downtown location near Powell's Books.

events.title: Hollywood Theatre
events.notes: Film Action Oregon dba Hollywood Theatre. Historic landmark, namesake of Hollywood District.
events.practical_tips: Check calendar for free community screenings and special events. The nonprofit theater shows independent, classic, and rare films. Less crowded on weekday afternoons. Historic 1926 landmark.

events.title: Ground Kontrol Classic Arcade

pricing.weekend_cover: Cover charge during peak weekend hours

programs.name: Free Play (2nd Thursday)
programs.notes: All-ages noon-5pm ($6), 21+ 5pm-midnight ($12). Unlimited play on 100+ games.

programs.name: Free Play (Last Wednesday)
programs.notes: All-ages noon-5pm ($6), 21+ 5pm-midnight ($12). Unlimited play on 100+ games.

events.notes: Since 1999. Games from Golden Age of Video Arcade.
events.practical_tips: All-ages until 5pm daily, then 21+ only. Weekday afternoons are quietest. The $6 all-ages free play (noon-5pm) is best value. Free Play events on 2nd Thursday and last Wednesday monthly. Can be loud and crowded on weekend nights.

events.title: Guardian Games

programs.name: Sunday Open Play
programs.notes: Demo library, game instruction, 'board game sommelier' host

events.practical_tips: Sunday Open Play (12-6pm) is free and welcoming to newcomers. Staff 'board game sommeliers' help find games and teach rules. Board games, card games, and tabletop RPGs available. Good place to meet people with similar interests.

events.title: NAYA (Native American Youth and Family Center)
events.notes: 40+ programs. Youth Centered, Family Driven, Elder Guided. Over 40 years serving Portland.
events.practical_tips: Open to all community members, not just Native Americans. Culture Nights (1st & 3rd Wed 6-8pm) are welcoming to newcomers. Check calendar for community dinners and art workshops. Elder services and youth programs available.

events.title: IRCO (Immigrant & Refugee Community Organization)
events.notes: Since 1976. Serves Oregon and SW Washington immigrant/refugee communities.
events.practical_tips: Offers cultural events, ESL classes, and community programs. Open to everyone regardless of immigration status. Staff speak many languages. Multiple locations including Africa House and Pacific Islander & Asian Family Center.

events.title: Oregon Historical Society

pricing.blue_star: FREE (active military + families, Memorial Day-Labor Day)

events.notes: NOT part of Bank of America Museums on Us program.
events.practical_tips: FREE for Multnomah County residents with proof of residency (Measure 26-221). Museums for All provides free admission for low-income families. Focuses on Oregon history. Usually not crowded. Downtown location near Portland Art Museum.

events.title: Oregon Jewish Museum and Center for Holocaust Education
events.notes: Closed Mon-Tue and major holidays including Jewish holidays.
events.practical_tips: Free first Sunday of every month. Also free with SNAP/WIC. Free for children under 12. Small museum - good for a 1-2 hour visit. Holocaust education exhibits are thoughtful and respectful. Open Wed-Sun 11am-4pm only. Old Town location.

events.title: Five Oaks Museum (formerly Washington County Museum)

events.notes: Named for historic gathering site of Kalapuyan Indians. Collection (40,000+ artifacts) transferred to Washington County.
events.practical_tips: CLOSED as of December 2024 due to funding cuts. Collection transferred to Washington County.

programs.notes: Social crafting at local bars. Fun evening activity with creative people.

events.notes: Nonprofit creative reuse center with free/low-cost craft events
events.practical_tips: Nonprofit creative reuse center with low-cost art supplies. Sunday Crafternoon is great for trying new crafts. Low-pressure environment perfect for creative expression without spending much. Materials provided for most events.

events.title: Independent Publishing Resource Center (IPRC)
events.address: 318 SE Main Street, Suites 155 & 145, Portland, OR 97214
